title: Wagga Tigers exit Southern NSW women comp after one round | The Daily Advertiser
body_text:
Only one round into the new season and there has already been a big change in the Southern NSW Women's competition.
Subscribe now for unlimited access.
or signup to continue reading
Despite taking to the field in the hot weather-impacted start to the season, Wagga Tigers have withdrawn from the 2026 season.
It's seen an adjustment made to the draw for the remaining seven rounds.
After coming into the competition in 2023, after a false start the year before, Tigers are yet to win a game in the club's history.
Despite having good numbers before Christmas, coach Brendon Post felt they had no other choice with only limited numbers available.
"We made one of those hard decisions," Post said.
After concerted efforts to boost the team, including drawing a number of experienced players from Albury, the Tigers had 25 players training early in their preparations.
However numbers continued to dwindle before they took on Charles Sturt University in the delayed round one clash on Saturday, January 31 where the Bushpigs scored a 9.9 (63) to 0.0 (0) victory.
"A couple went to other clubs, job opportunities came up after a couple which took Friday nights off the table for them, we had four or five new girls, brand new to the sport, come to training sessions and just thought the potential for injury was maybe more than they thought so they decided not to play at the end and all of a sudden we got down to 10 or 12 players which makes it a bit hard," Post said.
One of the issues players highlighted was the lack of a home ground, with Robertson Oval unavailable due to cricket season, and the impact it has on the rest of the club coming in support with Tigers often playing in double-headers at other venues.
Friday nights can also be a deterrent as can players juggling a number of different sporting endeavours and the large number of teams based in Wagga.
Post has been the driving force behind the team since its inception and has already turned his focus on trying to get a team on the field for 2027.
"We'll just try to recruit and look forward to going again," he said.
"The girls that stayed, the current players, took it on the chin pretty well and they are all quite adamant they are going to get out there and do a bit of recruiting like the club does to try to grab some girls for next year and fire up again."
With the competition now down to 14 teams the bye has been removed from the draw.
It's the second late change in as many seasons with Leeton-Whitton withdrawing on the eve of the 2025 campaign.
AFL Southern NSW community football and competitions manager Luke Olsen wanted to limit the impact of the withdrawal on the rest of the competition.
"There's no byes, which is good, they play every week and it's minimal changes," Olsen said.
As such North Wagga, who was due to tackle Wagga Tigers will now take on Griffith, who was scheduled to have the bye, at Narrandera Sportsground on Friday, February 6.
Meanwhile Mangoplah-Cookardinia United-Eastlakes will be looking to back up a win over grand finalists Collingullie-Wagga after the completion of round one on Monday, February 2.
The Goannas led at every interval and dominated much of the final quarter, with six scoring shots to win to take a 4.11 (35) to 4.3 (27).
They now take on premiers Brookdale, which will be the first game for the Bluebells after their round one clash with North Wagga was unable to be rescheduled.
Southern NSW Women's draw
Round two
Friday, February 6
Temora v Marrar 6.30pm at Temora Recreation Ground
Narrandera v Northern Jets 7pm at Narrandera Sportsground
East Wagga-Kooringal v Collingullie-Wagga 7pm at Gumly Oval
Charles Sturt University v Turvey Park 7pm at Peter Hastie Oval
Ganmain-Grong Grong-Matong v Coolamon 7.30pm at Ganmain Sportsground
MCUE v Brookdale 7.45pm at Maher Oval
Griffith v North Wagga 8pm at Narrandera Sportsground
